I.  INTRODUCTION   
1.  During the 2012 country programming review mission, the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) through the Hunan Provincial Chang–Zhu–Tan Resource-Conserving 
and  Environment-Friendly  Society  Office  (RES)  requested  policy  and  advisory  technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The TA was included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan, 2013–2015 for the PRC.2 A TA reconnaissance mission was 
conducted on 15–18 March 2013. Government concurrence with the impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  was 
obtained in a 27 May 2013 email. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Chang–Zhu–Tan city cluster, located downstream in the Xiangjiang River watershed 
in Hunan province, is industrializing rapidly and resource use is degrading the environment. In 
2007, Chang–Zhu–Tan was designated as an experimental zone for resource conservation and 
environmentally friendly development. Chang–Zhu–Tan is central to the economic development 
of Hunan province, contributing 78.7% of the provincial gross domestic product; and 84.2% of 
the province’s emissions.3 Coal is the primary energy source in the province, providing 72.6%, 
followed by fuel oil (11.8%), hydropower (9.9%), and natural gas (1%). The heavy reliance on 
coal and oil as energy sources pose major challenges to the effort to transform the Chang–Zhu–
Tan  economy,  and  pursue  environmentally  sustainable  growth  and  development.  The 
population of Chang–Zhu–Tan is 40,227,500, and it is increasing at 6% per year. The gross 
domestic product is CNY1,548 billion, which increased at an annual rate of 12.8% per year in 
2011. Most revenues (89.4%) are generated by secondary (e.g., smelting, manufacturing, and 
food processing) and tertiary (culture, sports, and entertainment) industries. The per capita 
annual net income of rural residents in Chang–Zhu–Tan is CNY8,115, and of urban residents, 
CNY22,179; this is significantly higher than the Hunan provincial average of CNY6,567 for the 
rural population, and CNY18,844 for the urban population. Hunan province is noted for its 
agricultural  capacity  and  mineral  deposits,  but  environmentally  sustainable  development  is 
currently at risk from industrial pollution, high rates of natural resource extraction, and land 
conversion.4 
 
3.  The Xiangjiang River is the primary water source for domestic and industrial users in 
Chang–Zhu–Tan, and serves as a major transportation link throughout the  city cluster. Its 
capacity to meet these needs is being affected by urbanization and industrialization. Forests 
and other open land are being designated for conversion, affecting local hydrologic cycles, river 
levels, and water quality. A number of industries—including nonferrous metal, food processing, 
petroleum and chemical, building materials, and paper—are major sources of pollution in the 
watershed. Large volumes of residential and industrial sewage and solid waste are produced in 
Chang–Zhu–Tan; most (about 77.0%) of the industrial sewage is treated, but only a small 
fraction (2.3%) of solid waste receives treatment. Pollution and waste inputs are affecting the 
availability of potable water.

4.  Chang–Zhu–Tan covers 96,853.4 square kilometers (km2); 22,340 km2 (23.1% of total 
area) is under cultivation and 48,618 km2 (50.2%) is under forest cover, including 451.1 km2 
(0.47% of the total area) designated as urban green area cover. Urban construction accounts 
for 2,156.8 km2 (2.2%). The remaining 23,738.2 km2 (24.5%) includes residential areas, mining, 
water conservancy, road and/or transportation areas, and unused land. Current forest cover, 
however, may potentially be converted to other uses under certain circumstances (e.g., national 
construction projects). The limited size of green areas and tree cover along the riverbanks is 
insufficient  to  meet  the  needs  for  required  ecological  services,  such  as  maintaining  water 
quantity  and  quality,  air  purification,  pollination,  and  biodiversity  habitat.  Ecosystems  are 
severely degraded, and threatened by pollution, overextraction of resources, and conversion 
(e.g.,  from  a  forest  ecosystem  to  a  grassland  ecosystem).  Climate  change  impacts  are 
exacerbating these challenges, and the annual average temperature has increased by 0.14°C 
per decade since 1961 (footnote 3).     
 
5.  The Hunan provincial government (HPG) states that a major problem is the lack of 
established  structural  policy  promoting  ecological  protection;  constraints  include  unclear 
regulations and authority, weak enforcement, and lack of financial incentives. The PRC’s 12th 
Five-Year Plan (2011–2015) requires implementation of eco-compensation. This could include 
market-oriented compensation mechanisms (e.g., a national eco-compensation fund, enterprise 
reserve fund, and balanced transfer payment in key ecological zones) as an incentive. As a 
designated  experimental  zone,  Hunan  is  implementing  eco-compensation  trials.  However, 
despite  several  advances,  practical  solutions  are  still  lacking,  and  a  systematic  and 
comprehensive eco-compensation mechanism and policy framework are needed, particularly in 
the water sector. Upstream users are threatening downstream water supplies. The framework 
needs to (i) identify environmental policy gaps and/or opportunities and perverse incentives, (ii) 
rank environmental threats and mitigation actions, (iii) calculate environmental and ecological 
costs and/or benefits, and (iv) recommend an implementation mechanism. Changes in the land 
use plan, such as increasing reforestation and nature reserves along the Xiangjiang River, are 
required to help in regulating water quality and abundance. Specific eco-compensation scheme 
details that need to be identified include the types of environmental services to be provided, the 
geographic and financial scale, the identity of buyers and sellers, the institutional arrangements 
and legal framework, mechanisms to monitor and evaluate progress and compliance, and the 
conditionality and allocation of payments.  
 
6.  The HPG seeks to address constraints to environmentally sustainable growth through a 
mix of well-developed strategies and policies, including pollution controls, appropriate land use, 
natural resource conservation, and financial incentives. A well-developed eco-compensation 
mechanism can help in supporting the HPG’s efforts through the provision of financial incentives. 
This TA will address gaps in the regulatory and policy framework for an eco-compensation 
mechanism  for  the  Xiangjiang  River  watershed  in  Chang–Zhu–Tan  through  analyses  of 
ecological  characteristics,  threats,  and/or  mitigation;  cost–benefit  analysis  (CBA)  and  other 
economic  analyses;  and  specific  eco-compensation  requirements.  The  TA  will  build  on 
recommendations and lessons from previous international experience and ADB studies, such as 
using eco-compensation to support integrated river basin management—a subset of integrated 
water  resources  management  (IWRM).5 The  outcomes  will  be  used  primarily  as  decision-
making support for the HPG in the construction of a resource-saving and environmentally 
friendly society in the Chang–Zhu–Tan experimental zone.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be the improved environmental quality in the Xiangjiang River 
watershed  of  Chang–Zhu–Tan  city  cluster.  The  outcome  will  be  a  strengthened  eco-
compensation mechanism and policy framework to improve water quality and abundance in the 
Xiangjiang River watershed. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will have three outputs: (i) completed analyses of environmental threats to water 
quality and abundance, including their interrelationship with natural resource and land use in the 
Xiangjiang River watershed; (ii) recommendations for the design and implementation of an eco-
compensation mechanism and policy framework; and (iii) strengthened government capacity in 
the environmentally sustainable use of natural resources and land to improve water quality and 
abundance.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  (i)  develop  an  eco-compensation  mechanism 
implementation strategy and action plan, including identification of priority activities, service 
providers, potential buyers, recommendations for changes in natural resource and land use to 
increase  water quality and  abundance,  and  a financing  plan;  and (ii)  increase  institutional 
capacity to implement IWRM and eco-compensation. 
 
9.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months. During the first 4 months, the consultants 
will  (i)  review  the  environmental  and  eco-compensation  policies  and  legal  framework,  and 
analyze current environmental and socioeconomic data; (ii) identify environmental threats and 
their impacts, including climate change projections, water pollutants, droughts, and floods; and 
(iii) conduct a CBA and other financial analyses. 
 
10.  During months 5–8, the consultants will (i) prioritize threats based on technical criteria; 
(ii) review the current spatial plan, based on potential threats and economic opportunities; (iii) 
review current management practices; (iv) prioritize economic approaches and actions based on 
the CBA and other financial analyses; (v) design improvements to the legal and regulatory 
framework and management practices; (vi) conduct a survey of willingness to participate in eco-
compensation; (vii) facilitate a working group to develop the eco-compensation mechanism; 
(viii) design  an  eco-compensation  mechanism  and  policy  framework;  and  (ix)  conduct  a 
workshop to discuss preliminary results. 
 
11.  During months 9–16, the consultants will (i) write a draft eco-compensation mechanism 
strategy and action plan that identifies priority projects, makes recommendations for changes in 
natural resource and land use, and includes a detailed work plan, budget, and financing plan; 
(ii) provide training, capacity building, a provincial study tour, and institutional strengthening in 
eco-compensation, sustainable natural resource use, IWRM, CBA, and other financial analyses; 
and (iii) conduct workshops to inform and jointly review TA results. ADB and RES will jointly 
prepare  a  knowledge  product  regarding  eco-compensation  and  sustainable  resource  use 
targeted to policy and decision makers. 
 
12.  The major assumptions considered include: (i) HPG departments will adopt relevant 
strategies, targets, and activities to and support the cost of implementing the eco-compensation 
mechanism and policy framework; (ii) relevant HPG departments have sufficient understanding 
of and are committed to the need for an eco-compensation mechanism and policy framework; 
and (iii) relevant HPG departments have sufficient political strength to ensure that cross-sector

4   
actions and recommendations for implementing the eco-compensation mechanism and policy 
framework will be generally supported. 
 
13.  The  key  risks  considered  include:  (i)  the  conflicting  priorities  for  environmentally 
sustainable economic development (some departments may be unable to reach consensus on 
management strategies required for implementing an eco-compensation mechanism for the 
Xiangjiang  river  watershed);  and  (ii)  funding  is  insufficient  to  fully  implement  the 
recommendations required for implementation of the eco-compensation mechanism and policy 
framework after TA completion.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $725,000, of which (i) $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and (ii) $225,000 will 
be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Multi-Donor  Trust  Fund6 under  the Water  Financing 
Partnership Facility administered by ADB. 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration and per 
diem  for  counterpart  staff,  including  secretarial  assistance  and  translation  services;  office 
accommodation and supplies; domestic transportation; access to relevant government data and 
studies for the consultants’ use; meeting and/or office facilities, including other support to the 
consultants  as  required;  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The RES will be the executing agency. 
 
17.  A TA management office will be established in the RES Division of Development to carry 
out day-to-day operations. The director of the Division of Development will serve as executive 
director  of the TA  management  office  and  will  be  responsible for coordinating  operational 
matters and technical collaboration with the consultants. The RES will provide office space, 
access  to  communications  and  copiers,  and  logistical  support  for  TA  implementation.  The 
executive  director  of  the  TA  management  office  will  also  be  responsible  for  submitting 
reimbursement claims for approved expenditures for logistical support for training, seminars, 
and conferences. 
 
18.  The  RES  will  convene  meetings  and  workshops  attended  by  relevant  offices  and 
departments during the inception, interim, and final stages of TA implementation. These will 
include the departments of agriculture, forestry, mining, water resources, and others at the city 
and provincial levels. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months, tentatively starting on 1 December 2013 
and ending on 31 March 2015. The consultants will submit to ADB an inception report within 
6 weeks of commencement, and an interim report 7 months after commencement. A draft final 
report  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  12  months  after  commencement,  and  a  final  report  at 
conclusion. The inception, interim, and draft final reports will be subject to review by ADB and

20.  The TA will be carried out by a team of consultants to be engaged through a firm, which 
will provide 10 person-months of international and 42 person-months of national consulting 
services.  TA  implementation  will  require  (i)  four  international  specialists  (team  leader  and 
integrated watershed management specialist, environmental economics and eco-compensation 
specialist, hydrology specialist, and water pollution specialist); and (ii) eight national specialists 
(deputy  team  leader  and  environmental  policy  and/or  institutional  specialist,  integrated 
watershed  management  specialist,  eco-compensation  specialist,  environmental  economics 
specialist,  hydrology  specialist,  climate  change  specialist,  water  pollution  specialist,  and 
geographic information system specialist). ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The consulting 
firm will be selected using simplified technical proposals and quality- and cost-based selection, 
with a quality–cost weighting ratio of 90:10 given the high technical complexity. Disbursements 
under the TA will be  made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will reimburse the TA management office 
for approved logistical support costs for training, seminars, and conferences. ADB will undertake 
intensive review and supervision by fielding missions at critical stages of implementation—
particularly inception, interim, and final reviews—and by extending regular support from ADB 
headquarters and the PRC Resident Mission. 
 
21.  The  TA  results  will  be  disseminated  through  the  release  of  the  project  reports, 
workshops, and media releases by ADB and the RES. A knowledge product will be developed 
and disseminated in hard copy by ADB, the PRC Resident Mission, and the RES; and will be 
posted on the ADB website. Outcome evaluation will follow ADB guidelines, and will be provided 
to the RES. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $225,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant 
basis  to  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Eco-Compensation 
Mechanism and Policy Framework Study for the Xiangjiang River Watershed of the Chang–
Zhu–Tan City Cluster, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  A consulting firm will be engaged for the technical assistance (TA). The successful firm 
will  have  prior  experience  and  demonstrated  expertise  in  eco-compensation,  developing 
environmentally  and  economically  sustainable  natural  resources  and  land  use 
recommendations, integrated watershed management (IWM), low carbon development, and 
conservation planning. Experience working in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) is preferred. 
Under the supervision of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Hunan Provincial Chang–
Zhu–Tan  Resource-Conserving  and  Environment-Friendly  Society  Office  (RES),  Division  of 
Development, the consulting firm will (i) lead TA implementation; (ii) assemble and support the 
specialists; (iii) facilitate and promote the involvement of civil society organizations; (iv) support 
the active involvement of local resource personnel; and (v) use the firm’s pool of national and/or 
international expertise, as necessary, to achieve the TA outputs. All international and national 
staff  must  be  fluent  in  spoken  and  written  English,  and  hold  graduate  degrees  or  have 
equivalent experience. For international staff, the ability to speak and read Chinese is preferred. 
For national staff, provincial-level experience, particularly in Hunan province, is preferred. All 
consultants will provide inputs to the eco-compensation mechanism and policy framework. It is 
estimated that the TA will require 10 person-months of international and 42 person-months of 
national consulting services. The geographic focus is the Xiangjiang River watershed in the 
Chang–Zhu–Tan city cluster of Hunan Province. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  Team  leader  and  integrated  watershed  management  specialist  (international, 
3 person-months). The team leader will have (i) at least 15 years of experience in IWM and 
environmentally sustainable development; (ii) prior experience conducting quantitative analyses 
(i.e., modeling, statistical, or economic analyses) and environmentally sustainable watershed 
planning; (iii) a graduate degree in environmental planning, ecology, IWM, or equivalent; and 
(iv) demonstrated ability to manage a team, prepare reports, facilitate workshops, and work with 
civil society organizations, the government, and local communities. Working closely with team 
members, the RES, and other stakeholders, the team leader will 
(i)  prepare the detailed TA methodology and work plan; 
(ii)  lead  TA  implementation,  including  coordinating  of  team  inputs  and  ensuring 
timely delivery of project outputs; 
(iii)  act as the main liaison between the RES and the project team; 
(iv)  review, edit, and compile the inputs of the other team members; 
(v)  support the other team members in their assigned tasks; 
(vi)  lead the review of international best practices in IWM and/or planning, and of 
payment for international services; and oversee the review of eco-compensation 
in the PRC, provincial institutional frameworks, and natural resources and land 
use to increase water quality and abundance; 
(vii)  lead the development of the eco-compensation mechanism and policy framework; 
(viii)  facilitate stakeholder meetings, TA planning workshops, and team meetings;  
(ix)  prepare training materials in integrated water resources management (IWRM) 
and watershed management and/or planning; and 
(x)  prepare  and  submit  progress  reports  to  ADB  and  the  RES,  including  brief 
quarterly progress reports; and the knowledge product, inception, interim, and 
final reports.

Appendix 3  11 
3.  Environmental  economics  and  eco-compensation  specialist  (international,             
3 person-months). The specialist will lead the effort to identify potential eco-compensation 
sources  (including  the  government,  international  development  partners,  and  private  sector 
investments), and develop specific mechanisms in the context of IWM and environmentally 
sustainable  development.  The  specialist  will  have  (i)  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in 
developing and implementing eco-compensation, preferably with prior experience in the PRC; (ii) 
demonstrated expertise in calculating economic cost–benefit analyses (CBAs) incorporating 
ecological  valuation,  marginal  abatement  cost  curves,  and  other  economic  and/or financial 
analyses; (iii) a graduate degree in environmental economics or finance or equivalent; and (iv) 
knowledge of eco-compensation mechanisms such as payment for ecosystem services and 
carbon markets. The specialist will 
(i)  research and evaluate eco-compensation and other funding options for improving 
water quality and abundance; 
(ii)  assess potential mechanisms for benefit sharing in the watershed; 
(iii)  calculate CBAs and other analyses of potential actions and/or activities in IWM; 
(iv)  design mechanisms to mobilize additional, more diverse financing from public 
and private, and/or domestic and international sources; 
(v)  identify  appropriate  eco-compensation  schemes  and  make  policy 
recommendations, including regarding the types of environmental services to be 
provided, the scale (geographic and financial), the identity of buyers and sellers, 
the institutional arrangements and legal framework, mechanisms to monitor and 
evaluate  progress  and  compliance,  and  the  conditionality  and  allocation  of 
payments; and 
(vi)  prepare training materials on eco-compensation and environmental finance.  
 
4.  Hydrology specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist will collect and 
analyze  information  related  to  the  hydrology  of  the  Xiangjiang  River  watershed,  including 
projected  climate  change  impacts.  The  specialist  will  use  hydrological  models  to  make 
projections, if data are not available. The specialist will help in identifying opportunities for 
actions and/or activities in IWM and provide inputs for the sustainable land use strategy and 
action plan. The specialist will have (i) at least 15 years of experience and demonstrated 
expertise in evaluating watershed hydrology, preferably with prior experience in the PRC; (ii) 
prior experience incorporating climate change impacts into models; (iii) demonstrated expertise 
in IWRM; and (iv) a graduate degree in water engineering or freshwater ecology, or equivalent. 
The specialist will 
(i)  oversee data collection regarding Xiangjiang River watershed hydrology, and 
model scenarios of likely hydrological responses to changes in climate or land 
use; 
(ii)  make recommendations and/or provide inputs for IWRM actions and/or activities;  
(iii)  assist in the analysis of the current environmental status and threats, and their 
inter-relationship with sustainable natural resources and land use; and 
(iv)  develop training materials on IWRM. 
 
5.  Water pollution specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist will lead 
the effort to identify major point and nonpoint sources of water pollution, and develop specific 
recommendations regarding appropriate land use and mitigation of pollution inputs for the eco-
compensation mechanism and policy framework. The specialist will have (i) at least 15 years of 
experience in the identification, potential impacts, and mitigation of water pollution and its 
relationship  with  land  use,  preferably  with  prior  experience  in  the  PRC;  (ii)  demonstrated 
expertise in IWRM; and (iii) a graduate degree in environmental engineering or ecology, or 
equivalent. The specialist will

(i)  identify point and nonpoint sources of water pollution and potential impacts, and 
estimate their significance or importance by sector; 
(ii)  identify potential mitigation actions, and make recommendations and/or provide 
inputs regarding appropriate watershed management and land use; and 
(iii)  prepare training materials on IWRM.

(national, 9 person-months). The specialist will lead eco-compensation and environmental 
policy development and institutional coordination in the context of IWM and environmentally

least  10  years  of  experience  in  developing  and  implementing  eco-compensation  and/or 
environmental  policy  and  institutional  collaboration;  (ii) demonstrated  expertise  in  strategic 
planning and policy formulation; (iii) a graduate degree in environmental policy, the environment,

workshops, and work with civil society organizations, the government, and local communities. 
The specialist will 
(i)  help in coordinating team inputs and the timely delivery of project outputs;   
(ii)  act as the alternate liaison between the RES and the project team;  
(iii)  help  in  the  review,  editing,  and compilation  of  inputs for team members for 
reports and the knowledge product, and in supporting team members in their 
assigned tasks;  
(iv)  organize  and  facilitate  stakeholder  meetings,  TA  planning  workshops,  team 
meetings, and provincial study tour;  
(v)  assess policy gaps and opportunities in collaboration with colleagues related to 
eco-compensation, environmental safeguards, and IWRM; 
(vi)  assess potential mechanisms for institutional collaboration and coordination; 
(vii)  develop draft environmental and eco-compensation policies and regulations in

(viii)  provide training to the RES and other government entities on the environmentally 
sustainable  use  of  natural  resources  and  land  to  improve  water  quality  and 
abundance. 
 
7.  Integrated  watershed  management  specialist  (national,  5  person-months).  The 
specialist will help in identifying appropriate watershed management actions and use. The 
specialist will have (i) at least 10 years of experience in IWM, planning, and policy development; 
(ii)  prior  experience  developing  recommendations  for  environmentally  sustainable  natural 
resources and land use to improve water quality and abundance; and (iii) a graduate degree in 
watershed management, environmental planning, or equivalent. The specialist will 
(i)  gather  information  and  assist  in  the  analyses  for  the  eco-compensation 
mechanism and policy framework; 
(ii)  assess  potential  mechanisms  for  benefit  sharing  in  the  Xiangjiang  River 
watershed; and 
(iii)  provide training to the RES and/or other government entities on sustainable land 
use. 
 
8.  Eco-compensation specialist (national, 4 person-months). The specialist will help in 
identifying  potential  eco-compensation  sources  (including  the  government,  international 
development partners, and private sector investments). The specialist will help in developing a 
specific eco-compensation mechanism in the context of IWM and environmentally sustainable 
land  use.  The  specialist  will  have  (i)  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  developing  and 
implementing eco-compensation (including payment for ecosystem services, and voluntary and

(i)  gather  data  and  assist  in  the  evaluation  of  funding  options  for  the  eco-
compensation mechanism and policy framework;

and the conditionality and allocation of payments; and 
(iii)  provide training to the RES and other government entities on eco-compensation.

expertise in calculating CBAs and other economic and/or financial analyses; and (iii) a graduate

(i)  gather  data  and  assist  in  the  evaluation  of  potential  options  for  the  eco-

CBAs and other economic and/or financial analyses for actions and/or activities

(iii)  provide training to the RES and other government entities on environmental 
finance.

analyze  information  related  to  the  hydrology  of  the  Xiangjiang  River  watershed,  including 
projected  climate  change  impacts.  The  specialist  will  use  hydrological  models  to  make

(i)  gather  data  regarding  Xiangjiang  River  watershed  hydrology,  and  model

(ii)  assist in the analysis of the current environmental status and threats, and their

analyze information related to climate change impacts (environmental, economic, and social 
impacts) and projections (predicted changes in temperature, precipitation, soil moisture) in the 
Xiangjiang River watershed. The specialist will use simple climate models to make projections, if 
data are not available.1 The specialist will help in identifying opportunities for climate proofing, 
adaptation, and mitigation actions and/or activities in IWM; and provide inputs for the eco-
compensation mechanism and policy framework. The specialist will have (i) at least 10 years of 
experience in climate change; (ii) demonstrated expertise in evaluating potential impacts of

(i)  gather data regarding point and nonpoint sources of water pollution, and potential 
impacts; and help in estimating the significance of importance by sector; 
(ii)  gather  information regarding  potential mitigation  actions,  and  help  in making 
recommendations regarding appropriate natural resource and land use; and 
(iii)  provide training on water pollution.

specialist will support the development of a project database and decision support tools. The 
specialist will have (i) at least 10 years of experience with geographic information systems 
(GISs), and demonstrated proficiency in GIS software used by the government (e.g., ArcInfo) 
and the ability to develop databases; (ii) ability to efficiently compile and harmonize large 
amounts of digital data; (iii) ability to produce high-quality decision support tools, especially 
maps; and (iv) a graduate degree or equivalent training in environmental planning or GISs. The 
specialist will 
(i)  review  available  digital  data  provided  by  the  RES  and  from  the  provincial 
development plan, based on data requirements for the TA; and 
(ii)  in  coordination  with  the  RES,  assess GIS  capacity  in  Chang–Zhu–Tan;  and 
building  on  existing  GIS  data  and  databases,  make  enhancements  and/or 
revisions in a format that can be used by the RES, which will include: 
a.  identifying  data  sources  and  obtaining  data  layers  required  for  the 
Xiangjiang River watershed (e.g., county boundaries, towns, roads, mines, 
protected  areas,  rivers,  topography,  vegetation,  ethnic  minorities,  and 
biodiversity  hotspots),  including  data  established  through  previous 
projects; 
b.  verifying the accuracy of key data layers (e.g., protected area boundaries 
and status); 
c.  inputting the social and ecological data provided by the RES and team 
members, and developing data layers for key attributes identified by the 
team and the RES, but that may not exist (e.g., community-protected 
areas, “key  biodiversity areas”, wetlands, and local sacred sites); and 
d.  preparing  maps  as  required  by  team  members  (e.g.,  location  of 
agriculture, roads, residential areas, mines, forestry areas, protected area 
networks, and water bodies in the Xiangjiang River watershed).
